Sexto Proyecto de Proteccion Social -
            analisis ambiental/Sixth Social Protection Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Jefes de Hogar (Heads of Household)
            Program Project (also the Sixth Social Protection Project
            for Argentina) is the workfare part of a social safety net
            launched by Argentina in April 2002 to alleviate the impact
            of rising unemployment due to the worsening economic crisis.
            A stipend of 150 Argentine pesos per month is provided to an
            unemployed head of household in exchange for participation
            in 4 hours of work in a workfare subproject. The four
            project components include the financing of workfare
            subprojects in community services, minor construction,
            repair, expansion, maintenance or remodeling of schools,
            health facilities, basic sanitation facilities, small roads
            and bridges, culverts and canals, community kitchens and
            centers, tourist centers, and low-cost housing. This report
            focuses on the likely negative environmental impacts from
            these subprojects and proposes measures to mitigate them.
            Expected impacts to land and water include soil saturation
            and salinization, water-borne diseases, an altering of the
            lifestyle of affected people, surface and groundwater
            contamination and the reduction of water quality because of
            industrial and farm chemical use, the proliferation of algae
            and undergrowth due to canal and waterway blockage, change
            in the water table due to overuse, disturbance of aquatic
            life, and erosion and sedimentation. Impacts caused by
            constructing secondary roads in areas that receive a lot of
            rain include flooding and erosion because of stripped
            vegetation and inadequate drainage, and sedimentation in
            surface waters. Road construction sites should be carefully
            selected to avoid affecting critical forest areas and animal
            habitats. The report recommends monitoring the nutrient
            level of water, water discharge level, water salinity, water
            use management, the conditions of canals and the drainage
            system, flood controls, the presence of disease vectors,
            erosion control, waste disposal, contaminant treatment,
            measures to protect workers from hazardous substances,
            waterway protections, demographic change in alluvial plains,
            socioeconomic impacts, and institutional and technical
            capacity of the agencies having oversight.
